review: Headspace is a very easy app to get around, has many options for children and teens, is accessible, and visually appealing. The app is however expensive (if they don‚Äôt register with a nonprofit partner), and may not be stimulating enough to keep children coming back. Strategies such as yoga, meditation, and breathing techniques ‚Äúare helpful for promoting well-being and resilience in youth‚Äù and Headspace allows teens to have access to skill building resources that they can take with them wherever they go (Laser & Nicotera, 2021). This access can be incredibly helpful for children who have experienced trauma, as they may not feel comfortable meditating within a large group. Headspace allows them the opportunity to do it on their own in whatever space they feel the most safe in. Meditation and mindfulness training are extremely effective interventions for those who have experienced trauma because they ‚Äúenlist the whole person, and not just the mind‚Äù, as ‚Äútrauma affects both the mind and body‚Äù (Laser & Nicotera, 2021). Headspace has exceeded in the way in which it allows ‚Äòregular‚Äô people to access training and skills about meditation that would have previously been harder to find. The issue however, has to do with the discipline and time commitment needed to truly benefit from the effects of regular practice. Many of the studies that Headspace mentions on its website state the benefits associated with mindfulness for youth. The issue is that in all of these studies, the meditation or mindfulness activities were led by researchers or other people who were able to hold the participants accountable, or remind them to participate. Headspace does offer the choice to be reminded once a day by the app, but it is easy to ignore. I believe that Headspace is very beneficial when used regularly. However, when used sporadically, the effects of mindfulness techniques are fleeting, and truly incorporating those skills into everyday life becomes less attainable. Overall, Headspace is a well-rounded app for adolescents, and may help them alleviate some of their stress or anxiety, in a calming and very accessible manner.
title: Headspace for Teens

review:
I want to share my enthusiastic recommendation for this incredible meditation app. It offers a wide range of high-quality content and features exceptional teachers, making it an app that I confidently recommend to multiple people. Moreover, their customer service is not only professional but also highly responsive, adding to the overall positive experience.

However, it is worth noting that when I recently decided to cancel my annual subscription, I discovered that they do not provide partial refunds. Even if you have several months remaining on your subscription (in my case, 8 months), they adhere strictly to their policy and do not offer any reimbursement for the unused portion. This policy is clearly outlined in their terms and conditions for auto renewal. I feel it is important to inform my fellow subscribers about this aspect so that they can make an informed decision.

In my personal journey, I eventually switched to another meditation app that better suited my preferences and needs. The content provided by the new app resonated more with my meditation goals, prompting me to explore alternatives. While I still acknowledge the positive aspects of this app, I believe it is essential for individuals to find an app that aligns closely with their interests. Therefore, if you are seeking a meditation app that caters specifically to your preferences, I encourage you to explore other options as well. Regardless of this consideration, I firmly believe in the importance of continuing your meditation practice. Keep exploring and stay committed to your journey!
title: Amazing App but‚Ä¶be wary of renewal terms!

review: Overall, I really enjoyed using the app and have contemplated extending my free trial to a monthly subscription. I would rate the app a 4 out of 5. As a 2nd year grad student, that has a full-time job, runs a small business and is living through a pandemic, I found the Headspace app to be the perfect resource for learning how to manage time for relaxation, self-care and stress management. The Headspace app‚Äôs engaging content, user friendly interface, and personally customizable dashboard enabled a hassle free and positive experience. Regarding areas for improvement, I think monthly/annual subscription rates can be negotiated. $13 dollars a month not including in-app purchases is quite high in comparison to similar apps that cost around 3-5 dollars. I think Headspace can expand user accessibility by providing a much larger language selection, as well as incorporating content and instructors that demonstrate diversity, equity and inclusion specifically regarding ableism and age. In the book, Working with Adolescents : A Guide for Practitioners, Julie Anne Laser and Nicole Nicotera explain that teenagers on average spend at least 10 hours each day interacting via social media platforms and the internet. The authors recognize that although media usage among adolescents may present risks for youth, media also presents benefits and can foster community, accessibility to information that impacts youth knowledge and useful programs that teach adolescents how to deal with depression and chronic fatigue. Due to our current life circumstances with the COVID-19 pandemic withthe exception of few educational institutions and workplace settings, life in this day and age has transitioned from in person activities to life online. The impact of burn out, stress, physical and mental health concerns on youth and adolescents has dramatically increased. Apps like Headspace offer youthaccessible ways to foster stress management, increase mental and physical health, practice self-care techniques and learn about mindful meditation strategies. As Laser and Nocoteradiscuss, messages received via media have effects on adolescent behavior. In this case, Headspace fosters the belief that individuals can and should create life-changing habits that promote individual and community mental health and wellbeing.
title: Apps for Adolescents Review

title: Best Mindfulness App

review:
I have heard of apps similar to this one before and figured I would give it a try to relax me since with finals are just around the corner and deadlines are getting closer. I decided to put my goal at reducing stress and anxiety and the first thing I got was  prompoted to a ‚ÄúFeeling overwhelmed‚Äù talk down to get myself relaxed and calm. The voice was not all that calming and relaxing, but he did have an accent that was very mesmorizing that helped let go of some tension. 

After setting some goals for myself Headspace created a list of things for me to accomplish throughout the day and the first thing was to take five deep breaths. What I loved about this was the music was very calming, but still had some upbeats it helped with when we were holding, breathing in, and exhaling. Another great component was there was a little face that would do the exercise with you and when you would inhale it would smile.

The way this app relates with anxiety and panic attacks is, I think this can be beneficial to help get our heart rates down, get us to focus on other things, and help us relax. I think this would be incredibly useful in situations of discomfort of nervousness, I know this would help me and many others. Breathing methods help center us, by doing the five breaths with the app helped me feel more in control and calm of what I was doing. I have shared this app with my family, as I know they have been going through some hard times lately and they could use something to relax and destress them. 

Stress can be hard to manage, and a lot of the talking ‚Äúpodcasts‚Äù seem to help with trying to get you to let go or trying to find other things to distract ourselves with so we dont become too overwhelmed. Overall, I think this app has some benefits it helps calm you, center you, and puts you at peace. It certainly helped my anxiety be more managable while doing assignments and it helped me get in the right direction for the next couple of hours with my work and overall wellness. I can definitely see myself using this in a store to distract myself from my anxiety because this type of stuff can be grounding.

review:
I am a teen who struggles with ADHD, Autism, Depression, and C-PTSD. I first tried this app years ago on a campaign to improve my mental health and reduce my su**idal feelings and thoughts. For the month I had this app, my mental state felt so much better. I was more present. Mindful. Genuinely feeling like I could find the strength to go on.

Fast forward 30 days, and my subscription ran out. I tried to keep the habit up on my own for a while, and succeeded at least a bit; but it just wasn‚Äôt the same. So I gave up, and saw the app as something I‚Äôd get again ‚Äúone day‚Äù, when I could afford it. Losing the free version of the app made it even worse (but I don‚Äôt blame you; this company is too helpful and beneficial to people‚Äôs lives not to deserve support). I‚Äôve found other ways to try to help my mental health and my life, but that feeling that everything would be ok that this app gave me was gone.

Then, I found out about the Peer Health Exchange program giving free membership to teenagers. I‚Äôm 18 (but honestly hardly feel older than 15, even now), and so I thought I wouldn‚Äôt be accepted‚Äîbut I still tried anyway. When I got the link and realized I could finally use this app again, it literally made me happy enough to want to cry on the spot. I‚Äôm using the app again, and I couldn‚Äôt be happier about it.

Thank you so much for your program, both Peer Health Exchange and Headspace. Thank you for giving a depressed and poor teenage girl like me a chance to get some headspace. üíó

review:
I was fortunate enough to receive a free membership to headspace at the beginning of the pandemic. 
I was as stressed and depressed as I had ever been. My mother had just passed away and I had moved to the other side of the country where I knew no one in the six months prior to Covid. 
The generous gift of that membership brings tears to my eyes today because of the enormous impact it has had on my life.
I was so miserable. I was drinking way too much as a measure to ease some of the misery and anxiety I was feeling which, of course, only contributed to it in the long run. 
In all honesty, I had been miserable for years. Self-medicating until numb and that‚Äôs all I had really hoped for. 
Head space changed that. Meditation changed that. 
I started slow at first, as these things do. I eventually realized I was choosing not to drink because it made the meditation feel better, be more satisfying somehow. 
It wasn‚Äôt a chore to stop drinking. I gladly chose to now that I had another way to not be in so much pain. 
It was a journey that took a couple years but one I never thought I‚Äôd have the will to make. I didn‚Äôt think my emotional damage could actually be healed or that there was really any other viable way to fix it aside from self-medication. 
I have never been so grateful to be wrong. 
I now have a significantly more peaceful, satisfying life. My interests are in things that make me feel good instead of just numb. I have interests now. That feels like a life. 
I wish I had invested in meditation earlier in my life but could not be more happy to have it now. 
Thank you, Headspace. You‚Äôve literally transformed my life.
title: Life-changer

review:
Was thinking of giving it 1 star‚Ä¶ below is why‚¨áÔ∏è

Headspace is truly a wonderful app.
It has evolved through time with new features made for every kind of person. New high quality content is constantly added. 

I started meditation and mindfulness through Andy‚Äôs book, ‚ÄúHeadspace Guide To Meditation and Mindfulness‚Äù and it was a game changer. Eventually I downloaded the app and, sometime after, I started paying annual membership. I do so without regret because of what the app offers. The opportunity to access guided meditation by teachers such as Andy is incredible!!  Everyday life is a fight, the world is going fast, our lives as well‚Ä¶for me, the app has become an necessary aide for motivation and resources. 

Precisely this is why I almost gave it 1 star. Everything is so magnificent it has generated dependency.  It is so good, that now it seems very difficult for me to meditate without it. It is as if I‚Äôve lost my ability, will, and/or discipline to acquire headspace on my own. Makes sense? Maybe. Foreseeable? Most likely. Inevitable? Not really. Could be just me? Definitely. As of writing this comment, I will actively work to put in practice meditation and mindfulness on my own again.

My advice for anyone reading the review is to go for it. Try it out, learn the basics and reap the benefits !!!  but be careful to practice being present and dealing with your mind without having to use the app. I believe the app can‚Äôt become essential in our lives. Good luck !

review:
I used Headspace just for bedtime stories for over a year, and just recently was told that the reason I‚Äôm not sleeping well is probably due to anxiety.  My husband was in a serious accident two years ago and the sudden caretaking duties were so overwhelming that I began to doubt myself in all realms of life.  My energy, mental capabilities, confidence, and low-key go with the flow attitude have still not recovered after two years.  

Despite being fairly averse to ‚Äúwoo woo‚Äù therapies and practices, I am a scientist (by profession and at heart) and the science behind the benefits of meditation is solid.  So I decided I should give it a try to reduce anxiety and regain some confidence and happiness.  Headspace is the only source of guided meditations I‚Äôve found for people like me who need a down to earth entry point that‚Äôs not spiritual, mystical, or hokey in any way shape or form.  The meditations are about focusing on your breath, your body, relaxing and letting go of thoughts, and becoming more mindful (ie, able to take things in stride without flipping out) and less worried.  

I‚Äôve gone through the ‚Äòbasics‚Äô courses and recently discovered the ‚Äòtoday‚Äô section, which has curated set of brief videos and meditations just for each day, and even incorporated the next session of whatever course you happen to be taking- now that‚Äôs what I do every morning.  I‚Äôve only just started, but I already feel much more calm throughout the day- I can get more done during my work day without shutting down from fear of responsibility and curling up on the couch for hours.  Headspace is giving me my life back. (Also therapy, but I get to use headspace every day!)

Fantastic stuff- keep it up, Headspace team!
title: Down to earth, great for beginners

review:
This app has saved my life. I have been using it with a membership since 2019 and have relied on it religiously over the years. I love the illustrations and videos. I am a visual learner so I appreciate how they break down numerous concepts with visual aids - it was also what first drew me to the app. I have seen the app go through a lot of changes, especially with the UI, and there is also SO much more in the app now than when I started using it. I like all of the different content available in addition to just meditation and the visual organization of everything. I have been enjoying the app‚Äôs latest update as it currently stands with a few exceptions‚Ä¶

1. I REALLY wish that the streak counter had a grace period. I struggle with maintaining my streak, (we all miss one day here and there) but it is very discouraging when I am finally on a long streak and miss one day and have to start over. It would be nice if there were some sort of encouraging message/reminder when you miss a day and your streak continues, but after missing 2 days it starts over. Apps like Duo-lingo are a good example of this function.

2. I wish there was a way to remove/hide courses from the daily meditations section/homepage. I don‚Äôt particularly like having 2 meditations back to back in the ‚Äústart your day‚Äù section. Then if you don‚Äôt complete it, it just lingers day after day. I also bounce between courses a lot and it would be nice to have a space in the app where all of your courses are located together.

3. It would be super helpful to have a filter on the search function for meditations. That way you could search by length, type, instructor, video, activity, etc. There is SO much content now; it can be overwhelming and difficult to find what I am looking for.

4. I love the yoga section, but I have done most of them multiple times and wish there were new ones added. I feel that section is still pretty limited but I am grateful for it as a resource and would use it more if there was new content being added. 

I have been using the paid/membership version of this app for over 4 years now and while I really do love it, these are all things that I have consistently felt would be improvements and hope that the developers take into consideration.
title: Long-time user, first-time reviewer

review:
Hate new design! Used headspace couple years ago when it just came up and it was so simple and straightforward! It was all about meditation and convenience! Then I got Calm app for free for one year and did not liked it all! There is way more guidance in Headspace especially for beginners! Mediations are much better in headspace! Andy you are the best! 

When I started using this app again couple weeks ago (November 2022) it is so different! Now, its even hard to find what you want! I have this ‚Äústart your day‚Äù on the main screen with checkmarks! I don't need that! Makes me look like leave things unchecked if I only do my meditation! Gives me some topics I am not interested in! Does not give me a choice to remove it or to modify my main screen. Designers and Developers nice try good job, I understand maybe you are trying to improve retention by developing habits or something else I don't know but this new start your day with checkmarks did not work for me.  I am not interested in power napping or listening to some random course on adversity, eating habits, or anxiety!

Maybe main page would look better with slots where I can keep my favorite courses: breath, continue last course, days on streaks and if I click on each one I go into details. Or if you at least give us a choice to modify it.

Liked previous simple design. Liked that in the past you did not need to go to the course info to change duration and videos would just pop in right away before certain mediation. I understand that now headspace is more than just a guided audio mediation app and you have so many courses. And have to redesign! 

Also bug alert: when closing information about mediation (at least in basics) mediation automatically starts which is quite annoying. Sometimes I want to see information about the course after the mediation and when I close it starts like ‚Äúwelcome back‚Ä¶‚Äù! 

Love you guys!

review:
After about a month of daily meditation it‚Äôs the only thing I‚Äôve found that can help me cope with my severe anxiety and panic disorder. But that first month is very very difficult, you have to stick with it every day. Then after the first month or two, I found (back in 2017) that I came to enjoy meditation so much it was easy and I‚Äôd happily spend hours at it, had a 300+ day streak at one point, then foolishly thought ‚ÄúI‚Äôm good now right? I wonder what happens if I just stop.‚Äù You cannot. Do not do that, stopping back in 2017 is one of the things I regret most in my entire life.

Lately it seems like trying to get into it, I can‚Äôt catch a break. I keep seeing unfortunate news events, having close personal losses of friends and colleagues, getting upset, throwing my phone aside and letting negative (and incorrect) thoughts like ‚Äúscrew yoga and meditation, it‚Äôs like fighting a forest fire with a squirt gun!‚Äù And reaching for a much more‚Ä¶ ‚Äúunskillful‚Äù coping mechanism, like Wild Turkey 101.

Mindfulness meditation does work eventually though, I promise! And just now as I‚Äôm having a very real panic attack over some very real current events (war) that my friends & colleagues might not survive, I reached for the app and their SOS mini-meditations helped me out of that state of panic.

You don‚Äôt necessarily need to use this app, no one ‚Äúowns‚Äù mindfulness meditation, but I like it, and I like giving money to the folks who got me into it üôÇ

review: The content of the app, the meditations, are absolutely fantastic. However the app itself needs some serious revisions. This is a review of the app and not the app‚Äôs content. It‚Äôs incredibly frustrating to navigate around. My absolute favorite feature and what put headspace on the map for me in the first place is courses. Courses are meditations for usually 10 days in a row that focus on the same topic. When I was first using headspace around 10 years ago, courses were the foundation of the headspace experience and are the core of what made it unique and enjoyable compared to other meditation apps. The developers have decided to all but hide these courses, burying them under a mountain of other content I‚Äôm not interested in. The main page is a todo list of various meditations throughout the day with the vast majority being one-offs. I understand that choosing to focus on one-offs means that they are chasing the more casual user and that‚Äôs fine. But for the daily user it‚Äôs frustrating that it‚Äôs so difficult to access my favorite part of the headspace experience. Even if the front page of the app is hand curated, I could be at a very different point in my life or emotions than other users and need a different set of tools than the standard ones being presented. For an app whose goal is to increase mindfulness there is a lot of distraction and frustration. Ultimately all I want is for the meditations to be better categorized so it‚Äôs easier to find the specific content a user could want instead of having to spend time searching through content that is organized haphazardly and unhelpfully.
title: Frustrating experience finding courses

title: Calm

review:
I‚Äôve had a paid headspace subscription for one year now.  For me, the meditations got really tedious after just a few months because they all follow the same basic format: the narrator gives some words of wisdom for about a minute, followed by silence and the occasional prompt, and then closing with some more dialogue from the narrator.  Every meditation was more or less about the same, regardless of what the topic was.  The ‚Äúwords of wisdom‚Äù were trite sayings I‚Äôve heard a dozen times in passing from self-help gurus, yoga instructors, 12-step program people, etc, and the rest of the meditation was mostly silence.  There‚Äôs not much substance.
I‚Äôve always thought it was crazy to leave a negative review for a meditation service because, after all, what doesn‚Äôt work for me may help others. I was planning to just cancel and be done with it but decided to leave this review based mostly on their difficult and shady cancellation policies.
You can‚Äôt cancel your subscription in the app - you have to log in to their website.  First red flag.  Good luck remembering your log-in credentials that you haven‚Äôt used for a year.  Once you‚Äôre in and you start the cancellation process, it begs you to stay: ‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù  ‚ÄúWhat if we gave you a discount?‚Äù  ‚ÄúHow about you sleep on it?‚Äù  I had to click NO for three different prompts.  Every step of the cancellation process is designed to be a road block and to make you second-guess your decision and stay on for another year.  Once I completed the cancellation, it logged me out without any confirmation.  When I logged back in, the website still said I have an active subscription.  I never thought I‚Äôd have to fight a meditation app, but it‚Äôs 2021 and this is how the world is now.
title: Tedious and Difficult to Cancel

review:
Headspace is a great supplemental tool to use if you‚Äôre looking for emotional and physical well-being whether you‚Äôre having a typical bad day, you‚Äôre having trouble sleeping, or you‚Äôre having a major life crisis. Of course it‚Äôs not a cure-all, but I‚Äôd definitely say it‚Äôs a help-all. It‚Äôs helped me in managing anger, fear, anxiety, sadness, grief, loneliness, being over-excited for events, ect. It‚Äôs even been of one the tools I use to calm my mind and help prevent migraines if I feel a small one coming on. 

Personal experiences:

One night, back when I was pregnant, I was panicking from the grief of my mother dying of brain cancer, and that night I felt I could barely walk because of the overwhelming emotions I was having, but prayer and headspace helped me calm myself enough to function again that night. 

When I moved to a city after living my whole life in rural areas, headspace and prayer were what helped me overcome the feelings of being trapped and anxious. I started out with the free trial which was great. Then I was gifted the premium and I enjoyed that, though I wish it was always free ;). I‚Äôm back to the basics now, and it is still helpful.

Overall, headspace has helped me calm down on a regular basis to levels I didn‚Äôt think were possible for me. Headspace along with counseling have led the way for me to overcome negative thought patterns I‚Äôve had my whole life. 

Headspace has taught me mindfulness meditation and helped me accept myself and appreciate my present reality. These techniques has showed me how to be as calm and clear headed as God intended when he created our bodies and minds to have those calming mechanisms such as deep breathing and visualizations already built in. Headspace can just help you discover those. 

Headspace changed the way I help myself and my children cope with strong emotions. It‚Äôs helped me be more present and grounded in my own life, and that‚Äôs huge for me. Thanks, headspace.
title: If you‚Äôre overwhelmed, Headspace can probably help

review: Title says it all
title: Everything is locked unfair and to much money

review:
Update:  Nine months in, I wanted to provide a few updated thoughts.  The content is impressive and varied.  There is something for everyone.  The variety of instructors allows you to explore different styles and voices.  They are all outstanding in their own ways.  We‚Äôll done.  

On the down side, the organization of the app is poor.  The only way to bookmark something to explore at a later time is to add it to the favorites list, which defeats the purpose of a favorites list.  And getting to the downloads is a layered process.  They should be accessible from the home page. One click away.  

 Also, It would be nice to be able to guide  what goes into the daily feed.  Often I find the content ‚Äúselected‚Äù for me is more suited to a teenager or young adult who is new to meditation.  I‚Äôm 72 and have been an on and off practitioner for years.  The advanced classes I‚Äôm working on rarely show up on the home screen, while all the intro to meditation and combating teen angst does.

Also, I‚Äôm finding that since Andy‚Äôs departure, some of the new content is geared toward activism instead of mindfulness.  Instead of sitting on the side of the road passively observing the traffic, it‚Äôs now about jumping into the traffic to stop the cars.  Consequently I‚Äôm exploring other programs and am undecided if I‚Äôll renew my yearly Headspace membership in January.  

Original 5 Star review February 2022:   This is a great introduction to guided meditation and mindfulness. I‚Äôve been an on and off ‚Äúpractitioner‚Äù of meditation since the mid 1980s, when I lived in Thailand, but I recently felt the need to recenter and refocus. A few months ago I came across a Headspace introduction on Netflix and was so impressed by its clarity and simplicity that I now have the app and a years subscription. For the monthly price of a single latte, I now sleep better, keep life‚Äôs ups and downs in perspective and look forward to the day. Well done Andy and crew. And thank you.

review:
Revised: I have experienced over 1100 meditation sessions on this app; ideally, I use it twice a day. My reason for being here, is to mediate.

The app does contain incredible sessions and the meditation process does work. Previous editions of this app had a different intention and overall appearance, before Headspace merged with Ginger, before Andy and Rich stepped away, before, it became Headspace Health. The current intent of the app is beyond meditation, so it‚Äôs marketed and organized, in that way.

On organization, this app was more direct and efficient at the beginning of 2022, that is, if you want to go beyond the first opening page.

It takes more scrolling and searching to find previous content, than it did in February 2022. I find all of this to be chaos. Given the price of this app it should be less confusing.

The app pushes diversity to connect the universal experience of meditation; if you want a sampling of instructors, you can find that under beginning meditation. If you have been meditating with Andy Puddicombe, his name is not listed in the same way. Right now, I have chosen to stay with Andy, I supplement that with other content beyond this app.

The Netflix series, Guide to Meditation, my first Headspace experience, was beautifully created; I was in awe of the innovative visualizations. I highly applaud Netflix for talking the risk to visually tackle this topic. I loved the Netflix imagery and felt instantly at ease with Andy, as my guide. I accepted this figurative animation as my mentor; I never though about his race or gender.
On Headspace, Netflix: Bravo!!!

 I have watched Andy Puddicombe‚Äôs TedTalk, and have read his book. I‚Äôve listened to online videos of his thoughts, as well.

I do like the pace and format of his meditation style; he is easy to understand, and speaks clearly in English; I mention only this because online meditations from other non-western countries are often, not crisp, and I miss words.

Andy is both straightforward and empathetic, compassionate and disciplined; he comprehends difficult emotions and is articulate. Andy has a natural gift for training, to communicate, and, for having patience. He understands this amazing balance between the mind and body. It‚Äôs a tightrope act and following him, as a guide, helps me to stay on focus.

The ability to speak this see-saw, between thinking and feeling, between the mind and body, between opposing forces, is a gift. His gift.

I do think so highly of Andy, I have chosen to have him as my Headspace mentor; his meditations are a 10+, on a scale of 1-5.

Non-the-less, it doesn‚Äôt why you are here.

The effect and peace of mind/body is worth the app price, but this place is a disaster. It contains too many links, to the same content. I think the idea is to cover more bases, to collect and direct more users, more emotions, to similar experience, but the end result is only more time lost searching in confusion.

This app needs to tighten up all the extra links, to be mindful of our time spent scrolling.

We are here to streamline, aren‚Äôt we?
title: On the 3rd Year with Headspace
developerResponse:
{'id': 29915933, 'body': "Thank you so much for taking the time to write to us. We genuinely appreciate your candor. To start, our intent behind the collaboration with Disney and Star Wars was meant to help reach new audiences, to help further demystify meditation for new and current members, and to hopefully expand on the unstuffy, approachable content that our members love and appreciate. We are, however, so sorry to hear that you're not a fan of this collaboration. 

Our goal at Headspace has always been to reach as many people as we can with the tools to help live healthier and happier lives. Our intention is not to stray away from what makes Headspace so special and unique. If anything, our hope is to continue offering a variety of beneficial content and topic areas to help our members find mindfulness in all areas of their lives.

To answer your question more specifically around Andy - he has been on a gradual journey over the past two years to step back a bit, to refocus his efforts on philanthropy, family and other endeavors. He only stepped back recently, however, after dedicating years to recording timeless meditations and content that are designed to guide you on your meditation journey for years to come. Andy's insight, guidance, wisdom and teachings are foundational to the Headspace experience. 

But, we value you as a member of Headspace and I really take to heart your thoughts and feedback. I do hope that you can continue to seek out Headspace as a supportive tool in your life. 

Thank you, again, for sharing your thoughts. I‚Äôm not sure if this response will make you feel better. But, I‚Äôm hoping it at least helps provide some clarity.\xa0 If you have any additional thoughts or feedback, please do not hesitate to reach out to help@headspace.com.", 'modified': '2022-05-23T15:28:43Z'}

review:
This app contains a wide variety of meditations for all sorts of goals (rest, presence, wakefulness, dealing with change, etc.). But it has three major pain points that grate on my nerves each time I use it:
1. There‚Äôs no end bell or gong for completing a meditation. Sometimes I‚Äôll do a wake-up meditation and keep sitting, listening for more narration minutes after the meditation has actually completed. I‚Äôd love the option to toggle on/off a gentle bell so I know the audio is over. (Then to disable it for sleep meditations where I don‚Äôt want to be woken back up.) Not all mediations have guided music or sound, so a bell would make it really clear that my session was over.
2. A PLAYLIST FEATURE. Oh my goodness it‚Äôs so frustrating to me that at night, I have to play either a wind down or an 8 hour night sound (such as rain, waves, etc.). I desperately wish that there was an option to create a nighttime playlist of a narrated wind down followed by 8 hours of rain, one flowing into the other without my interference. I could ditch my sound machine if this was a feature, which I really want to do.
3. No dislike option for meditations. I love the heart option, as it helps me remember and easily find meditations I like, but there‚Äôs no ‚Äúdo not show this meditation again‚Äù option. There are some audio voices I don‚Äôt like hearing and some nature sounds that are unpleasant to my ears and I‚Äôd love to better curate what‚Äôs displayed to me based on what I like and dislike. Having a reliable set of go-to favorites with no grating sounds/voices would be a real treat.

Decent app. Not mad I received half off for my year‚Äôs subscription from a Black Friday promo. But without these features, I likely won‚Äôt be renewing.
title: Okay; needs three significant changes

review:
I have been a Headspace user for several years now. I first found it back in 2016 after I graduated from college, I could only periodically afford to keep the app as expenses had been a challenge. But I always came back. Headspace has provided me with the resources and support I needed from a community. The approach to everyday practice is made so simple that I would practice on my own throughout the day. 

However, in the last year or so the app has become chaotic and monotonous. There are pop ups when I open the app to suggest new material -which feels like ads (triggering stress). The suggested material on the Today page is not customizable and not relatable. I‚Äôd be okay with one suggestion, but 6 is too much. In addition, every page you choose is advertising a meditation, rather than letting you explore. 

The app is saturated with advertising itself. People are burnt out on having things sold to them. I‚Äôm amazed that the app I once bragged about has lost its focus. What happened to the supportive community I once enjoyed connecting with?

Older meditations done by Andy created a sense of accomplishment, development of practice, and realistic changes. The practices were more diverse and engaging. 

Now, the meditations all sound exactly the same and most of the material is over crowding the app. I do not enjoy exploring the new content like I used to. 

Starting to think I will need to end my subscription after almost 5 years.

Very sad and disappointed. I hope Headspace realizes there app has lost its vision and has become messy and dull.

review:
I have been a subscriber to Headspace for quite a while now but am planning on finding a different app due to recent ‚Äúpolitically correct‚Äù content that I find inappropriate and offensive. 

Martin Luther King Jr. famously hoped that his children ‚Äúwould not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.‚Äù In contrast, it would appear that Headspace has now jumped on the ‚Äúwoke‚Äù bandwagon that EMPHASIZES  skin color, offering a platform to those who favor ‚Äúpeople of color‚Äù over ‚Äúprivileged‚Äù white people.

In particular, I‚Äôm referring to ‚ÄúRachel‚Äù and her ‚ÄúAcknowledging Our Privilege‚Äù so-called meditation. Instead of focusing on gratitude, acceptance, kindness, and how much we humans have in common, this woman is negative and divisive, ruminating about those who have privilege and those who don‚Äôt. She apparently craves a utopia in which we all happily end up at her ‚Äúfinish line‚Äù simultaneously. Anything less is the fault of ‚Äúprivilege.‚Äù And, in the midst of this thinly veiled rant, she admiringly quotes a member of Black Lives Matter, a self-avowed Marxist organization that is anti-white and anti-Semitic.

My ‚Äúprivilege‚Äù has also included heartache and hardship, and only 80 years ago my people were tortured and murdered in the worst genocide in this planet‚Äôs history. Instead of stereotyping individuals as disadvantaged vs. privileged, Rachel might want to meditate about her own intolerance and racism. I will not be made to feel guilty or ashamed because I happen to be white, and I resent bringing identity politics into what is supposed to be a positive, helpful app, not a fixation on victimhood and unfairness.
title: Don‚Äôt like politics creeping into a meditation app

review:
I should have reviewed this app years ago. 5 stars for sure. I‚Äôve recommended it to so many friends and have given it as a gift many times as well.   

I took a hiatus much of this last crazy year (ironically when I prob needed it the most) and when I recently came back, I see the total redesign with a ton of new content. So now we are scrolling through all this content, tons of media, noise, and suggested to set a myriad of notifications?!  Is this conducive to a quiet mind? No. In fact, every time I open the app I end up feeling super anxious.  I thought it was a one off, but it‚Äôs happened each time. It‚Äôs too much noise and it‚Äôs too chaotic at the time in the morning when I‚Äôm trying to start my day off right by focusing on presence, quieting the mind, and setting my intentions before leaping into my crazy day.  Now, instead of being a respite, a place for grounding, this app mirrors much of what life looks like these days and all social media apps.  Honestly, this really feels like Headspace ‚Äúsold out.‚Äù

Once you dig around and find what you‚Äôre looking for, Andy‚Äôs soothing guided meditations are still there, and I do love the ambient noise and low-fi tracks that have been added. I get it. You‚Äôre trying to corner the market on all things zen. Gotcha. There‚Äôs a BD team making very different decisions than our beloved yogis and zen masters. So....

In the spirit of both staying true to the mission AND in consumer satisfaction (which is of course, good business) I will offer the perfect solution, instead of canceling my membership (yet) bc Andy is the best. Create a customizable home page. Let me drag over only the things I want on my page.  It would be what I see when I open the app and no need to navigate elsewhere if I don‚Äôt want to.  I would personally choose to keep it uncluttered and super simple with my mediations and maybe some music. Others may do something diff. To each their own.   And when I‚Äôm not in mediation mode, maybe then I‚Äôll choose to dig around the other media and content to check out your new stuff, and drag and drop new favorites to my page.  But opening this app and seeing this chaotic stream of content is not sustainable for me, and I cannot imagine that I am alone in that.
title: Have loved for years but not the new 2.0 version

review:
I first downloaded Headspace in 2017. It was recommended to me by a friend after I opened up to her about having recurring episodes of anxiety and she told me to try guided meditation as it was helping her. 

So I downloaded it, tried it, and found that it helped me so much. Meditation quickly became part of my evening routine. Shower, brush teeth, get into bed, open up headspace, and meditate. 

Headspace has helped me to find the inner peace of my mind in the midst of turmoil. To always remember that blue sky. I would do the free guided meditations over and over, and I believe I have racked up about 3,000 + total hours of meditation. I would do the 5 minute mediations on my lunch breaks and the 10 minute ones at home. It helped me so much with my anxiety and overall helped quiet down my chaotic thoughts that were relentlessly swirling through my mind. 

I put my friends onto the Headspace app and told them that they could just do the free guided mediations over and over the same way I did. I posted the app to my instagram story and told my followers the same thing. 

This morning I logged onto the app and clicked on ‚ÄúBasics‚Äù and was met with a ‚Äústart your free trial‚Äù button. Confused, I went back to the menu and clicked it again. Same thing. I saw the lock icon next to the Basics and slowly realized that the app I used for the past 4 years to help manage my anxiety was no longer free and I couldn‚Äôt do the free guided courses anymore that I was so used to.

 This app that saved me in so many hard times, that helped regulate my mind and calm me down when I was feeling anxious, I could no longer access. I felt betrayed. I feel like this app that I cared so much for no longer cares about me, or maybe never even did. Something that is supposed to help people with their mental health is no longer accessible to those who cannot afford it. 

I‚Äôm not just disappointed, but I‚Äôm upset, confused, infuriated, anxious, and I just want to be able to meditate again with the sound of Dora‚Äôs voice guiding me in the background. 

I don‚Äôt know what to do.
title: Absolutely Disappointed

review: I‚Äôm sure many people are going to see the title of this review, and scoff. But just hear it out, and then maybe scoff afterwards. But, I started my headspace journey all the way back in 2019. I was in a very abusive situation, and in a bad moment, instead of spiraling, I reached out to a friend, asking for help. She was immediately there for me, suggesting I download an app called ‚Äúcalm harm‚Äù. It either didn‚Äôt exist on android, or I couldn‚Äôt get it. First on the list was ‚ÄúCalm‚Äù which I hadn‚Äôt really resonated with. Under it, was Headspace. The initial design drew me in, so I downloaded it, and immediately went into the 3 Minute Basics. I remember I had done a few back-to-back in that moment, because I didn‚Äôt wanna feel how I felt anymore. 2019 ended up almost being one of the best years of my life because of headspace. The world was so tough, and I was so exhausted. But I had headspace, and it‚Äôs practices when it did get too overwhelming. Now, unfortunately after about 9 months I fell back into that abusive situation, due to my own doing. And I lost all progress thinking I had it all figured out. But, about a month later, after wasting money, and not eating for two days due to stress. I‚Äôd had enough. I focused on me again, after being out of the situation I put myself in. And while it wasn‚Äôt as consistent as it was before, it was at least something. And when you can‚Äôt afford help, or, you are like how I was and didn‚Äôt want it at the time, you should at least start somewhere. And if I hadn‚Äôt, I know I wouldn‚Äôt be where I am mentally without them. I still struggle, simply because there are times I feel like I don‚Äôt deserve to, that I should sit with my anxious and sad self, because why not? But then I come back every time. And maybe, just maybe, I‚Äôll get back to where I was. And you will, too <3
title: Life Changing.

review:
I have followed the Basics course and lengthened my daily meditation little by little.This has been one of the great joys of my life. Keep at it and you will notice a shift in perspective that makes life more beautiful and wondrous. 

Be aware, daily stresses will impede meditative progress. Don't think meditation is not working when the stress of a job or relationship sends you spiraling. A few minutes of quiet breathe concentration each day can change your life.
title: Trust the Process

review:
I have used Headspace over the years and have thoroughly enjoyed everything that this app offers. There are a plethora of topics and resources on here that I am so happy are available to people who are either new to meditation or have been practicing for years. Meditation is one of the most effective tools and ways of reshaping/healing your brain. Personally, I have learned a lot from Headspace and meditation in general which I am so grateful for. It has been a few years since I have used the app, so I recently redownloaded it. 

Unfortunately, I have been noticing the uprise of subscription based apps. Especially for mental health or self-help apps. I am extremely disappointed that the price of a monthly subscription for this wonderful resource is quite expensive. I remember years ago, there was an option for a membership but they still had a wide variety of free meditations‚Ä¶ 

I do not really see the point to having the app if you are not going to pay. There is nothing that is unlocked besides the courses: finding focus, letting go of stress and managing anxiety. (Also the ‚Äúhow to headspace‚Äù is unlocked). This is very disappointing and though there are three *actually* free courses, I feel this falls short to selling a subscription. Sure, there‚Äôs a 7 day free trial, but there are many out there who cannot afford a monthly or yearly payment for a membership. Additionally, 7 days isn‚Äôt a long time to learn about meditation or even develop a habit of practicing (mainly for those who are newer to meditating, I am NOT talking about people who are experienced). At least have the basics unlocked so that people who may not be able to afford a membership can access the great help and tools that this app offers to begin on their journey of meditation.

I am unable to afford this subscription, therefore I will look to other apps or even Youtube at this point. Please make mental health resources more accessible.
title: Disappointed
developerResponse: {'id': 39038481, 'body': 'We appreciate your feedback! We recently updated the Headspace app to allow all new members to unlock the entire Headspace library through our free trial. We still offer free content outside of the app on social media channels and still offer K-12 organizations free memberships in the US, UK, Australia, and Canada.\r\n', 'modified': '2023-09-20T20:41:26Z'}

review: I found that using Headspace the way it‚Äôs set up to guide you through the day has been a huge waste of my time. I spend an inordinate amount of time going from one mini tutorial & meditation to the next, over & over again. Instead of going from one mini-tutorial-meditation to another and having to do the beginning breathing exercises repeatedly, wouldn‚Äôt it be more time efficient & helpful to a beginner meditator to do one longer breathing-tutorial-meditation ? You could conceivably begin with a 15 minute meditation & go on to 2 hours or more, according to the needs of the user. All of the other psychological tutorials and talks are fine, & I have benefited from one or two. But you need to do more than you have with meditation for those of us who have come to you for that purpose. Many are using meditation to get closer to God. We would like to learn more than one type of meditation practice because each kind of meditation has its own unique purpose. We would like to meditate with spiritual music & have it counted in daily statistics as a meditation along with meditating with your nature sounds. Personally, I love to meditate with the sound of wind for an hour or more. But according to your statistics, I haven‚Äôt meditated since July. I will be leaving Headspace for now, but I will return every year or so to see if you have added any of these ideas. I have always been able to meditate on YouTube with its variety of meditation styles. And with a membership that doesn‚Äôt break the bank. I was hoping that an app could help me to find what I‚Äôm looking for, but after having tried at least 30 or more meditation apps, I don‚Äôt think that our society is there yet. The closest I have come to finding a more spiritual app was in InsightTimer. But the organization was appalling last I was on it & then they changed it & I couldn‚Äôt find anything anymore. It‚Äôs a big job developing a meditation app that can be used by a wide variety of people. And from my experience, no one has been successful as yet. Good luck Headspace. I hope that in the future you‚Äôll be the first to come up with the perfect meditation app.
title: Definitely room for improvement

review:
Free trial gave me a good taste of learning a practice that could help me deal with stress/anxiety well, but more expensive than I was prepared to pay. After initiating the cancellation process, Headspace offered a 50% discount to help me stay with it, and I indicated, yes I will keep the annual discount at that price! But then when my free trial was over, I was charged the full price. Not sure what happened‚Ä¶maybe there was a promotional code?

 I have reached out through app support to find a solution. I hope Headspace will come through for me. Headspace developers, please help your new customers with a clear path to the discount you‚Äôre offering.
title: Beneficial! Be discount-aware though.

review: I did not like or use the app after purchasing last year and did not know (read the fine print) that they automatically renew if you don‚Äôt cancel before the renewal date. They automatically billed my PayPal account $69.99 and refuse to give it back. Basically a snooze you lose mentality while promoting themselves as a place of mindfulness meditation. Stealing $70 and refusing to give it back at the click of a button is not helping me stay calm. They are thieves and scammers. Buyer beware.

title: PLEASE fix app functions

review:
Headspace literally changed my life and I am, no joke, actually crying while writing this‚Ä¶ though I also ate a yummy dinner of üçÑüçã lol‚Ä¶ but all that ‚ú® aside, doesn‚Äôt change the fact that Headspace has made me a better person since I first joined in 2018.

I have been a paying member since 2019, starting with monthly but quickly opting for an annual membership. When 2020 rolled around and Covid-19 struck, Headspace put out a ton of content specific to the struggles related to the pandemic, they granted free access to more paid content, and they even offered a complimentary annual pass for those experiencing financial hardship due to the pandemic. IMO that says a lot about a company.

In that time, I have completed 2453 sessions of an average length of 37 minutes. 

I had a 600+ day streak that was only broken because I was on my sick bed with Covid and completely out of it for 24+ hours. I currently have a 257 day streak.

I have meditated with the app for a total of 91,614 minutes. That‚Äôs 1526.9 hours, 63.62 mfing days, or 0.1743 YEARS. And that number only tracks meditation minutes, it doesn‚Äôt take into account the countless hours of other outstanding content (like their exercise videos, podcasts, some music playlists, sleepcasts [one of my favs, think grown-up bedtime stories, but incredibly descriptive to the point of being almost immersive at times], etc.). 

Thanks to the good habits Headspace has helped me develop ‚Äî like a daily meditation practice, combined with greater mindfulness during day-today moments, and break many bad ones ‚Äî like alcoholism and prescription drug addiction, disordered eating, intrusive thoughts of suicide.

I am a better, happier person. I am a better parent and spouse and all-around general human. 

I would subscribe to a lifetime membership if they had one. This app is worth every penny. 

If you‚Äôve made it this far in my review, I know you are making a decent effort to find a good app to help you on some aspect of your life as well. Let me save you some time: Your search ends here. Download it now. Start today, just 10 minutes. Make a commitment to show up on a schedule that works for you. Take advantage of the free trial membership and put it to good use. You‚Äôll thank me later. 

Mush love, friend! ‚ù§Ô∏èüåàüçÑ‚ú®‚òÆÔ∏è
title: Worth every penny, would subscribe to lifetime membership

title: Why does it have to cost
developerResponse:
{'id': 34801415, 'body': 'Thank you for your feedback! Headspace, like many businesses, has a significant amount of running costs in order for us to produce the content and products that we offer. We employ over 250 people in the US and the UK - including animators, illustrators, project managers, finance controllers, and customer experience representatives, as well as a full internal engineering team and marketing/community managers to make sure our message is being spread. Not to mention all the scientists that we work with to help us prove the validity of our products. All of these people have families, mortgages, rent, and food to buy in order to live healthy and happy lives.


We feel very proud that we can play a part in helping them live a life that promotes health and happiness. We also believe that our products provide value to the world and that is why we must charge a fee: to run a sustainable business and provide a healthy work environment for our hard-working team.', 'modified': '2023-02-10T19:05:25Z'}

title: Best app on my phone

review:
I began using this app during nursing school in 2014/15 and have used it sporadically, still purchasing a subscription since. I‚Äôve found it very helpful in helping to cope with inordinate amounts of stress, anxiety, anger, and loneliness - have shared it with family, friends, and patients. 
The only reason for 4/5 instead of 5/5 is because living in such divisiveness and polarization, I do my best to remain objective and focus on what connects us locally, regionally, nationally, and globally - something I‚Äôve also heard meditation guides suggest in this app. There seem to be more (only) meditations, courses, etc. speaking to only one side of the political spectrum. As an MBA student, this seems shortsighted marketing, as a Registered Nurse it seems to show favoring some patients or clients over others also in need, and as a proud citizen and retired USAF veteran it feels divisive and not an effective way to bring our country or people of the world together. Peace.
title: Could be more balanced, but is beneficial for me

review:
I heard about Headspace when it was mentioned during 2 different lectures by specialists in the management of chronic pain. Because of my desperation to climb out of a 19 year abyss of chronic pain, 
I found your site & immediately joined your group. Although my journey began SO RECENTLY, I am surprised to see a gradual, positive change! 
As cynical as I have become about the archaic approaches of traditional Medicine ‚Äútreating‚Äù patients like me, with greed being a primary goal &/or secondary gain, that is a major compliment to you. ‚≠êÔ∏èThe more physicians have to lose, the less likely they are to embrace the science which clearly demonstrates that mindfulness & meditation practices can relieve and eventually cure chronic pain.‚≠êÔ∏è
I have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on 7 back surgeries for fusions which failed, injections monthly for years,  opioids, chiropractic, acupuncture & countless ‚Äúhealers‚Äù, many of whom were charlatans. The tragedy is when the opioid hysteria began, meds ( my ONLY relief) were abruptly withdrawn, leaving patients like me with no skills to manage pain & NO quality of life.
However, I believe that this ‚ÄúOpioid Hysteria‚Äùmay be the answer to many years of prayer.

It is nothing short of a MIRACLE that I saw those 2 lectures on YouTube during which a famous Pain Scientist & Physical Therapist made references to you. Having two masters degrees in the health profession, those two lectures really got my attention.
Headspace, along with educating myself on all the science which clearly demonstrates actual changes in the brains of patients who assume meditation practices, is giving me hope after almost 2 decades of suffering.
I can only express gratitude to you for the help and support I have received from you within a matter of days.
title: Gratitude

It wasn‚Äôt until the third month where I was truly hooked on the app! Headspace has this daily meditation plan that made it easy for me to start my day, and wonderful sleep music and sleep wind downs so I can fall asleep with a calm mind!  I can‚Äôt go back to not meditating and being in the present! Headspace is truly a life changer! Please invest into your future self by getting this app!

review:
UPDATE 7/2022: Headspace keeps getting better w/ the addition of new teachers that are relatable and have totally different experiences, approaches and backgrounds. The addition of Kessonga was key for the Headspace members with children. I really enjoyed the series post the teachers silent retreat. They have a candid round table discussion where they discuss their own struggles in life and in their meditatuon practices. It‚Äôs also so important that they talk openly about the everyday stress in their lives. They show us, by telling their own personal stories of their individual journey to and through meditation, that meditation doesn‚Äôt always look like a person sitting cross legged on the floor for 20 minutes or more saying ‚ÄúOm‚Äù but that it looks different for every person.

(This first entry was made in 2016) This app has found the sweet spot of "meditation for dummies" and "real" meditation. Having tried several methods of meditation at different points in my life but never "getting it", this app has given me hope that I just might be able to incorporate meditation into my daily life. I highly suggest you give this one a go!
title: Well worth the price! Keeps getting better.

review: Love the content. But I don‚Äôt understand how they can launch such a great app and have it create stress while trying to use it.  A few minutes into a session - once my iPhone screen locks - it closes the app and leaves me hanging mid breath. Which stresses me out! Dozens of other apps continue to play content after a phone auto locks (Spotify, iTunes, etc) so the fact this one doesn‚Äôt is really frustrating - which pretty much goes against the concept of the app. It‚Äôs 2022 - I should not have to manually unlock my phone to prevent an app from closing. If you want to use a sleep session and had to unlock your phone to do so it could potentially leave your phone open and running all night. I canceled my subscription because there are no real solutions online other than changing phone lock times which is an annoying workaround but not a solution.

review: I got this app years ago because I was having trouble sleeping and it was recommended to me by my high school guidance counselor. When I got it 3 years ago there were some pay features but they did have a select few free features. With this I got addicted to the free sleep music track they had it was titled Doze and was the only thing that could get me to sleep. Flash forward to now and you have to pay for EVERYTHING via a subscription? I can‚Äôt even use the app without giving you my money now? I know the same song is posted on youtube and I can still play it every-night while draining my phones battery, but it was nice to have access to the song and have my phone off to play it while I sleep and not drain my phone battery.
title: Used to Have Free Features

review: I‚Äôm a 16 year old with severe Gad, depression and a tendency to selfharm. I used to love this app when I was younger, because I had access to some of the meditations for free. But now it seems like you literally can‚Äôt do anything without paying. I know how good this app can be but not everybody is in the financial situation to purchase a subscription. I don‚Äôt have my own money and quite frankly if I ask my parents they‚Äôll just get upset with me, so I‚Äôm stuck. I feel like an app for mental health and wellness shouldn‚Äôt be fully payed. Everybody should have access to what this app offers without worrying about monthly/annual fees. It doesn‚Äôt have to be all of it, just some of the basics would be good even, like you had it a few years back. Again, this app was amazing the last time I had and used it somewhere back in like 2017/18? But that‚Äôs because I was able to get the help I needed when I needed it. Not for a price. I just wish it stayed the way it was before.
title: Payed

review: I get this free through my company and I‚Äôve already deleted it. I don‚Äôt like the content, the voices annoy me, the content is no better than what can be found browsing YouTube or meditation podcasts which are free, and the interface was maddening when I attempted to use this app at 3am on a stressed sleepless night when I reached for it. I thought my selection was for helping me get back to sleep and instead I get this video with a woman dr and grating voice talking about sleep tips ‚Äîwaking at the same time each day, etc. I didn‚Äôt want a vlog on sleep habits I wanted help falling asleep right then. And then I jumped around looking for a sleep meditation and selected mine with annoying music and a silly ‚Äúacting‚Äù voice that I could not take seriously. Closed that one and the music wouldn‚Äôt stop. Had to shut down the app to stop the music. Glad it works for some but definitely not for me. And yeah the positive reviews are suspect. Probably reviews in trade for offering deals for corporations who have wellness campaigns. If you want to save yourself some money, just search podcasts and YouTube for mediations white noise, etc.
title: Not for me

review: I will update this review hopefully as I actually experience Headspace, but at virtually $13 per month and the yearly costs, it would be both kind and wise to offer a palatable lifetime purchase option! Especially when you look at the inflation rises we are facing at this time! Thinking along that same line, paying for the app such amounts, I should NOT have to tolerate all the tracking you are doing, especially the amount that identifies me! Paying you for the app - ANY APP FOR THAT MATTER - should automatically relieve me of being tracked identifiably!!! You developers have long started taking too much liberty with a user‚Äôs privacy! You don‚Äôt need all that personally identifiable information for your app to work now, do you? I still treasure my privacy! I should AT LEAST have an option to turn off any tracking I truly don‚Äôt want.you certainly are the only developer who is taking too far. You aren‚Äôt even one of the worst privacy abusers. Some devs track everything, even sensitive or other information that is nebulously explained as simply sensitive or other information. That sounds like maybe hidden canmmeras are running as we step from the shower, or worse! Then, ‚Äúmake us pay for the rape!‚Äù You aren‚Äôt the worst privacy thieves, but you certainly can help clean up this environment! Would you please consider the lifetime payment option AND at least allow options on the tracking items? I would rather, however,if you just weren‚Äôt so noseyin the first place! Perhaps then your app would have a chance at five stars! Lastly, I pray this app is fully accessible to blind, low vision, and other disabled people! I hope I can just breeze through using your app! Thanks in advance for positively reconsidering purchase, privacy, and if necessary, accessibility of Headspace!
title: LIFETIME PURCHASE OPTION and PRIVACY!!!!

review: Headspace has great content - their sleep casts are really nice - but the app has been missing a couple of key features for years now and they don‚Äôt seem eager to address them. Most importantly, there is no option to use Airplay to stream the audio to a smart speaker like Sonos. (Headspace is also unavailable as a service within Sonos, which is a different issue.) The website version of Headspace doesn‚Äôt even have sleepcasts, so there‚Äôs no option to use Airplay that way either. We have been able to find some sleepcasts on YouTube, but that‚Äôs really kind of a weird workaround. We like Headspace a lot but they really should look into this, especially when other providers - like Calm - do offer Airplay and Sonos integration.

review:
I‚Äôm giving Headspace one star for a couple of reasons:
1.)  A misleading pricing and discount scheme. 
2.)  The content is repetitive and misleadingly displayed, especially when one considers the scammy pricing tactics. 
3.)  Poor customer service. 

1.) Headspace ‚Äúcosts‚Äù 70 dollars a year.   They give you a trial period that‚Äôs long enough to get a survey of the interface and maybe see some of the benefits of a mindfulness meditation practice. Once the trial ends, they bombard you with emails asking to purchase a year of access. 

DON‚ÄôT be like me and pay full price. Wanna know why?  They WILL start to send you a series of coupon codes. The discounts they will send you will increase until you get a coupon code for about half off. Wait until then, because the lowest price Headspace will offer you ($35-40) is the absolute the MOST this app is worth. 

2.) The app presents mediations in a way that makes them appear diverse and covering a wide array of challenges. Titles such as ‚ÄúCoping with Cravings‚Äù or ‚ÄúReturning to School‚Äù or ‚ÄúLosing a Job‚Äù look to cover a diverse array of topics. You might think that a diverse array of topics involve a diverse array of techniques:  you would be wrong. 

Headspace repackages the same two mediations with different titles to make the amount of content feel larger. Even with different mediation guides, the content boils in the majority down to two types: guided mindful breathing and a ‚Äúsun light‚Äù visualization. You better like these two because if you use a year membership regularly it WILL get repetitive and you WILL realize that you paid money for what is, mostly, the same content repeated over and over with the thirty second intro and outro changed. 

For me the sunlight visualization doesn‚Äôt work AT ALL and before halfway through a year of my subscription I kept trying ‚Äúnew‚Äù meditation courses only to discover they were the same mediations I‚Äôd been doing for months. This is when I realized I paid too much and got ‚Äúsoft scammed‚Äù by the pricing structure. 

3.)  Headspace asked for feedback and I raised these issues. I told them their pricing felt exploitative and scammy, and that their content was repetitive and not worth what I paid. They ‚Äúappreciated‚Äù my comments but failed to offer any real fix. No partial refund for the 6 months of subscription I didn‚Äôt use. They offered me a year free, which would reflect that I paid the MOST this app is worth ($35 a year). 

Maybe if they gave me lifetime access my $70 would have been worth it. 
The MOST a year should cost is $35, it really should be $20. 

Don‚Äôt be like me. Don‚Äôt pay full price for this app. Don‚Äôt reward Headspace‚Äôs shady pricing, recycled content, and lack of customer service.
title: Don‚Äôt pay full price for this app!

review: When I downloaded Headspace a year ago there were some free meditations available if you didn‚Äôt want to pay the monthly subscription but now everything is locked and there‚Äôs no access to anything without paying. Headspace is useful but anyone could easily use google or YouTube for their meditation needs so with Headspaces subscription plan, your really just paying for the convenience of it all in one app.
title: Nothing is free anymore
developerResponse: {'id': 27762273, 'body': "Thank you for your review; we'll be sure your feedback is heard. If you have any questions, please email our Support Team at help@headspace.com.", 'modified': '2022-01-31T12:47:54Z'}

review:
There are some great resources about mindfulness that can help you that don‚Äôt require a monthly subscription. John Kabat-Zinn has good content if you like reading. If you have audible you can get ‚Äúthe science of mindfulness‚Äù ‚Äî I highly recommend it as someone who took a therapeutic mindfulness class in grad school. It goes into why mindfulness matters and HOW it changes your brain and promotes wellbeing with regular practice, and different ways of doing it. The lecturer of the course has a website with FREE guided meditations that I believe are better than what this app offered at the time I had my free trial. Mindfulness-solution.com. More FREE guided meditations on self-compassion are on Kristin Neff‚Äôs website self-compassion.org.

The headspace app is great for people who have money to burn and want everything in a nice tidy package, but it is limited. If you really want to get into mindfulness, start with the above resources and make your own journey. Like John Kabat-Zinn said, ‚Äúwherever you go, there you are.‚Äù Every moment is an opportunity for mindfulness, and not a single cent needs to be paid.
title: READ THIS IF YOU WANT TO GET INTO MINDFULNESS

title: no free option

review: I have PTSD and suffer through chronic stress which also prevents me from getting a decent sleep most nights. I wanted to give Headspace a try and see if that could help me practice mindfulness as well as help me relax. I used the free trial to start and I have to say the UI is beautiful, the videos themselves are helpful and very well-made. My biggest complaint is how overpriced the subscription is. It is just too much money to spend every month or year for just one meditation app. Per month it is $12.99 and the annual price it is $69.99. That is basically as much as I pay for the usual streaming services that offer live tv, shows, movies, and sports. Unfortunately, I do not see the value in paying that much money for just one application on my phone. I think it is wrong that Headspace charges that much when there are people who are suffering everyday that are in need of relief, but they have to deal with a very large paywall to get there. I am not saying this application should be entirely free; however, that does not give this company the right to overcharge and take advantage of hurting people so that they can make a large profit. That being said, not everyone has the money to afford such a subscription. I certainly do not, so this is where I cross the line. Why not make it affordable for everyone instead of trying to wring out as much money as possible on those who are desperate?
title: Overpriced

title: All is money

I guess it‚Äôs they‚Äôre way of getting you use to certain sounds or meditations but it‚Äôs then ripped away from you. title: Not happy

review: Still waiting for the option to disable counting sleepcasts towards time meditated. They are NOT the same thing. Time meditated should reflect time meditated NOT time slept. Still waiting for the ability to play sleepcasts with airplay. Why can I play soundscapes with airplay through my nice Sonos speaker but not sleepcasts? I wrote my last review something like six months ago and gave it 3-stars. I‚Äôm taking one away now for failing to respond to/address my feedback. This app used to be beautiful because of it‚Äôs simplicity. The more crap they pack into it, the worse it gets. 09/27/2021: Follow up. This is actually the third time I‚Äôve written a review of this app. Are you going to respond to my questions? It‚Äôs been a long time (6 months, maybe a year?) since my previous review. Are you going to answer my questions? Does my feedback mean anything? I‚Äôve basically stopped using the app out of frustration. If I get the sense that Headspace cares about a long-time user‚Äôs perspectives enough to respond and actually improve the app, maybe I‚Äôll come back. 12/06/2021: I‚Äôm a paying customer! Is anyone going to respond to my feedback?! I‚Äôd appreciate acknowledgment.

review: When I first saw this app, I thought it would be absolutely wonderful because of all the features. But because literally over half the app is behind a paywall, I‚Äôm very disappointed. I wish we didn‚Äôt always have to pay to get great features on an app. Especially if it‚Äôs most of the app itself . I was fairly impressed when I first saw this app, now I‚Äôm just disappointed. If they can unlock more features instead of making most of the app $60, then I will update my rating. Update 11/12/21 Now apparently the 5 deep breaths needs a pay of 60+ dollars. Maybe it‚Äôs just a glitch and I‚Äôm making myself look crazy. But still. When I first saw this app, I really loved it! Now it‚Äôs nothing but a Paywall!! Many of us want to relax or focus or meditate . Isn‚Äôt that what headspace is for?? I‚Äôm a teen, and would love to meditate and use the varying features. I love this app except for the fact that I can‚Äôt access hardly anything! I have never been more disappointed. It‚Äôs like the owners are desperate for money. The only things that should be locked that need to be payed are part of the workouts and maybe the music but that should be all! There shouldn‚Äôt be paywalls behind every feature ! You could do SO much better headspace . SO much better. I apologize if this was too much , I just want more out of this app, because I wouldn‚Äôt want to switch to any other app. Headspace owners, please take this into consideration and the many other reviews asking you to make more things free. Thank you
title: Saw it , thought I‚Äôd love it, but was disappointed

review:
I use this app to be mindful. I do not want to be on my phone in bed- that is both begging for a noisy mind, and terrible sleep hygiene in general. 

Your Alexa and Google Home apps are total jokes. Completely unusable. Google Home literally doesn‚Äôt work at all unless I use my gmail account as my headspace username- which I do not want to do.

Obviously there is no Sonos integration either.

It is insane to me that the Headspace team is pumping out yoga videos and ‚ÄúMad Lib‚Äôs playlist‚Äù before working on this basic accessibility requirement. 

Please practice what you preach and let me meditate without fiddling with my phone.
title: Stop wasting money on content and work on accessibility and smart speaker integration

review: For a person who over thinks and has a lot of stress, headspace has really helped me out when I needed help. There is a 1 min breath at the beginning, there is a subject such as plants or nature that they talk about, a 10 min meditation, there‚Äôs even an afternoon yoga and a night meditation and more. The only thing that annoys me though is that you have to pay 12.99 per month for more than half of the meditations and workouts in this app. I do not use the app very often so I don‚Äôt have the premium, however if you will, I strongly recommend getting the premium.

title: Save Your Money

review: Feels like some tech-bro named Chad skimmed a wiki page on meditation and created this app with his parents money to turn people into corporate drones. Save money and use YouTube. Headspace is redundant and repetitive. You can only listen to the app on headphones or through your device so no option to cast to speakers so the nighttime stuff was useless for me. Deleted it and got my refund. Also depending on your current mental health situation, talk to your therapist before starting. My suicidal ideation came back stronger than ever within two weeks of using Headspace.
title: Repetitive, Garbage, Scam

review: I‚Äôve known this app from my backache self restored program coach. I first tried several days, then the trial was expired. After a while I found i can use it from youtube. Well it looks that always the same episode from the youtube every time I wanted to do my medication. Then I was bored with this. Until recently I received promotion like 20% , and 30% off for this app. Then I waited to the 50% percent off for this app. I know this is a kind of extra spent in my daily budget. But it eventually proved that this is very helped to pace myself with this Chaos time right now. The app pretty much tailored your needs to help you have mediation routinely in my life. And I felt very soothed with the Andy‚Äôs voice. I feel that I need to listen to human voice to heal myself with this unpredictable time. I meant COVID spread out time. Even though I‚Äôm vaccinated but there is still variants and new ones coming out. If you can have time to wait for the big promotion I definitely think it will be a worth. Otherwise I really think I need this app with my right now to keep practicing medication. Changing is a slow progress, and I believe that our life can go back to normally if I will still practicing medication daily or as much as I can.
title: It helps me in this self-quarantined time.

review: How come everything in the app cost money. Why not just make the entire app cost something and let the user be free in the app? This app was supposed to calm me but only stressed me out more after finding out the only way to use it was to pay a minimum of $12.99!
